content: Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) was a relatively new diagnosis in the 1960s. The term first appeared in the DSM in 1980, though the concept had been discussed in psychiatric literature since the 1930s.

McLean Hospital in Massachusetts is one of America's oldest and most prestigious psychiatric institutions. Founded in 1811, it has treated many notable patients including Sylvia Plath, whose experiences inspired 'The Bell Jar.'

During the 1960s, women were 2-3 times more likely than men to be diagnosed with certain mental illnesses. Feminist scholars have argued this reflected societal biases rather than actual prevalence rates.
To prepare for the role, Winona Ryder spent time interviewing women who had been institutionalized in the 1960s and consulted directly with the real Susanna Kaysen.

The film adaptation takes significant creative liberties with Kaysen's memoir. The character of Lisa is a composite of several patients Kaysen encountered, and many events were dramatized for narrative effect.
